flares.note: Impulsive occluded flare from behind the SE limb.
Concurrent brightening around S15E80 with AR 14294. Active Region 14299 was numbered on 2025-12-01 and this entry was updated.

This flare originated from a region near the northeast limb which has since been numbered as Active Region 14299, but was unnumbered at the time of the event. Updating this entry to include the correct Active Region association.

Secondary long-duration brightening following the M2.9 class flare from this same region, as a separate eruption with a separate CME signature. Active Region 14299 was numbered on 2025-12-01 and this entry was updated.
Active Region 14299 was numbered on 2025-12-01 and this entry was updated.

cmes.note: This CME is faintly seen to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2, and briefly before an Earth-shine event in GOES CCOR-1 imagery. There is no clear source.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. GOES CCOR-1 imagery was limited due to missing frames during Earth-shine event.

cmes.note: Faint loop CME front seen to the NE in all three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1) and closely followed by a fainter, narrower outflow. The source of this CME is likely indicated by very faint, slowly appearing post-eruptive arcades in the NE quadrant starting after 2025-11-28T02:30Z and very roughly centered at (N45E65), accompanied by minor dimming.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2) and confirmed by possible source (faint post-eruptive arcades and dimming).

cmes.note: Fast CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source appears to be a partially occulted C-class flare from a region beyond the eastern limb with visible filament ejecta released. A simultaneous additional filament eruption is seen north of this flaring region which also appears to be beyond the limb. It is possible the filament eruption from the northern portion was magnetically connected to the region closer to the E/SE limb, however limited viewpoints prevent from seeing the potential source region(s) more clearly.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit using SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the E/NE in GOES CCOR-1, SOHO LASCO C2/C3 (following a data gap), and in STEREO A COR2 imagery to the north. The source appears to be a filament eruption visible beyond the E/NE limb in GOES SUVI 304 starting around 2025-11-28T13:04Z. Wide moving/opening field lines are also visible along the NE limb in GOES SUVI 284 starting around 2025-11-28T13:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit using GOES CCOR-1, STEREO A COR2, and SOHO LASCO C3 imagery. The CME feature in STEREO A COR2 imagery appears significantly more narrow than what is visible in SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1. This is possibly due to the different perspectives, but uncertainty of the parameters cannot be ignored.

cmes.note: Bright symmetrical front to the E, seen in all three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1), overlapping in SOHO LASCO and GOES CCOR-1 with the preceding, also eastern, 2025-11-28T14:00Z CME. The source is not clear but there is a long narrow prominence eruption off/behind the NE limb seen in GOES SUVI 304/284 at 2025-11-28T16:38Z (maybe a bit too late to be the source of this CME).

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the fit of the front with SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 coronagraphs, confirmed by the possible location of the likely source (eruption of prominence off/behind the NE limb).

cmes.note: CME observed to the E in GOES CCOR-1, SOHO LASCO C3, and one late frame in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap, and not yet in SOHO LASCO C2 due to a downlink gap. The source is likely an M5.9 class flare from AR 14294 (S17E89) peaking at 2025-11-28T22:22Z, observed in GOES SUVI 131. Additionally observed as field line movement in GOES SUVI 171/195/284/304 and some filament ejecta in GOES SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 analysis, with no STEREO A COR2 imagery available at measurement time the source longitude of E89 is used, and longitude could vary by E95-E80.

cmes.note: CME seen to the east in all three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1). Its source could be the occulted M1.5 flare from AR 14294 peaking a bit after the start of the CME in SOHO LASCO C2 coronagraph. This source would require a significant deflection of the CME northward. This source is not certain since the CME is directed a little to north, while the flare location is S20, and the start of the CME is a bit earlier than the start of the flare, however part of this active region is possibly still behind the limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very approximate analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs. If the source is the simultaneously going M1.5 class flare from AR 14294 near the SE limb, there must have been a significant deflection of the CME northward.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the south in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. This event is obscured by the pylon and therefore not visible in GOES CCOR-1 imagery. The source may be related to a faint brightening observed near S55E40 starting around 2025-11-29T03:50Z seen in GOES SUVI 195 imagery. There is a coronal hole located north and west of the possible source location, which may account for the southeast deflection observed from the candidate source versus the measured parameters.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: Peculiar-shaped pointy-nosed CME front seen to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 starting at 2025-11-29T05:48Z and to the NNE in STEREO A COR2. This front is accompanied by another, directly eastern, CME front and closely followed by several other CME fronts. (There are at least 4 distinct fronts best seen in STEREO A COR2 at the same timeframe).

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the fit of the front in three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1). The source is likely one of the lobes of what looks like a three-pronged prominence eruption from/behind the NE limb, seen starting at 2025-11-29T05:36Z in GOES SUVI 304.

cmes.note: CME seen to the E in all three coronagraphs, SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1. It immediately follows the pointy-nosed front to the NE - the 2025-11-29T05:48Z CME.  The source of this CME is possibly the southern lobe of the three-pronged prominence eruption from/behind the NE limb, seen starting at ~2025-11-29T05:36Z in GOES SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with all three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1). The source is likely the southern lobe of what looks like a three-pronged prominence eruption from/behind the NE limb, seen starting at 2025-11-29T05:36Z in GOES SUVI 304.

cmes.note: Front seen directly N in STEREO A COR2, with no source found on the Earth-facing disk, so the likely CME longitude is -130 deg. The front is harder to ascertain in other coronagraphs, however there is a faint follow-up front following the pointy-nosed 2025-11-29T05:48Z CME, which fits well with this northern front seen in STEREO A at the longitude of -130 degrees (the likely longitude for this event).

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate/speculative analysis of the bulk front of this CME, based mainly on the fact that the CME is seen directly N in STEREO A COR2, indicating the longitude of -130 degrees and also 'confirmed' by the fit of the brighter front in COR2 with the much fainter front  to the NE in SOHO LASCO and GOES CCOR-1.

A very speculative analysis of the faint full halo shock front of this CME, based on the assumption that the longitude of the CME is approximately -130 degrees (since it is seen as full halo in STEREO A). However, there are multiple other fast CMEs happening simultaneously with this (including a faster 2025-11-29T05:48Z CME), so the shock may be associated with one of these other CMEs.

cmes.note: Symmetrical CME seen to the ENE in all three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1), overlapping with several earlier CMEs. No on-disk source was found for this CME in EUV imagery, but the fronts in three coronagraphs fit well with the front-sided longitude of ~-73 degrees.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the fit with three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1). No source has been found for this CME in EUV imagery.

cmes.note: Fast CME observed to the E in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2. The source is likely just on or beyond the NE limb, around N15-N25, observed as filament ejecta starting around 2025-11-29T08:32Z in GOES SUVI 304, field line movement in GOES SUVI 171/195/284/304, and a C7.0 flare in GOES SUVI 131 from an unnumbered region on the NE limb (N20E89). This CME appears to be deflected more equatorially and westward, triangulating around N05E79, with no source observed closer to these measured parameters.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. This event is not observed in STEREO A COR2 imagery despite availability of STEREO A imagery during this time, indicating that this event may be located on the far side of the STEREO A facing disk. The source location is likely far sided as there are no corresponding sources visible on the Earth-facing disk around the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the far-sided/uncertain source location and lack of visibility in STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: Faint CME observed to the E in SOHO LASCO C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2, missed in SOHO LASCO C2 due to a downlink gap beginning at 2025-11-29T13:36Z. The source for this CME may be more far-sided around the east limb, as the only observed activity is some weak field line movement in GOES SUVI 171/284 over AR 14294 around 2025-11-29T14:00Z which doesn't seem to match the CME signature much. However, swpc_cat triangulation puts the source at N00E82, near AR 14294.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between SOHO LASCO C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2. CME front is faint in white light but more noticable in running difference imagery.

cmes.note: CME observed to the E in GOES CCOR-1, STEREO A COR2, and SOHO LASCO C2/C3. This CME preceedes and is overlapped/collided into by CME 2025-11-29T17:00Z, which follows shortly after in a larger eruption from the same region. This source is an M2.9 class flare from an unnumbered region just on or beyond the NE limb (N20E89) peaking at 2025-11-29T16:07Z, observed in GOES SUVI 131. Also observed in GOES SUVI 131/171/195/284/304 as field line movement and a little bit of filament ejecta starting around 2025-11-29T15:42Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: CME observed to the E in GOES CCOR-1, STEREO A COR2, and SOHO LASCO C2/C3. This CME follows and overlaps/collides with smaller CME 2025-11-29T16:00Z, which erupts from the same region just before this larger eruption. This source is assocaited with a long-duration M1.0 class flare from an unnumbered region just on or beyond the NE limb (N20E89) peaking at 2025-11-29T17:16Z, observed in GOES SUVI 131. Also observed in GOES SUVI 131/171/195/284/304 as wide field line movement/EUV wave with northward deflection.

cmeAnalyses.note: The CME front is lopsided due to the eruption deflection and partial overlap with CME 2025-11-29T16:00Z. Best attempt at triangulating and following the leading edge direction is taken between GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2, which does miss some material on the northern edge that cannot fit in the swpc_cat tool's width due to the elongated CME shape, as such the half-width may be wider than 27 degrees.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. This event is not observed in STEREO A COR2 imagery despite the availability of STEREO A imagery during this time. The source is likely far-sided as there are no corresponding source signatures on the Earth-facing disk around the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the far-sided/uncertain source location and lack of visibility in STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source may be related to an eruption observed near the northeast limb starting around 2025-11-29T20:00Z as seen in GOES SUVI 131/171/195/284/304 imagery. A faint opening of field lines can be observed over the northeast limb at this time in GOES SUVI 195/284 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: CME observed to the E in GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2, partially in SOHO LASCO C2 before a downlink gap beginning at 2025-11-30T00:48Z and not in SOHO LASCO C3 due to a downlink gap beginning at 2025-11-30T00:06Z. The source is likely field line movement on/beyond the NE limb around 2025-11-30T00:10Z in GOES SUVI 171/195/284, associated with a long duration C8.0 flare (N19E89) observed in GOES SUVI 131.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2, and two available frames of SOHO LASCO C2 before its downlink gap begins.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1. This event is not observed in STEREO A COR2 imagery due to a data gap starting at 2025-11-30T10:23Z. The source is likely far-sided as there are no corresponding source signatures on the Earth-facing disk around the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the far-sided/unknown source location and data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: Narrow CME first seen to the NE by GOES CCOR-1 beginning at 2025-11-30T22:15Z. This CME is not visible in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 due to a data gap beginning at 2025-11-30T19:30Z, and is not visible in STEREO COR2 due to a data gap beginning at 2025-11-30T10:23Z. The source of this CME is minor field line brightening and movement seen along the East limb in GOES SUVI 195 beginning at approximately 2025-11-30T21:36Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky due to source along the East limb and lack of other coronagraphs to triangulate precise source location. Longitude fits between approx. E130 and E40.

cmes.note: Halo CME first seen to the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-12-01T02:48Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3, STEREO A COR and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. The source of this event is an X1.9 class flare which peaked at 2025-12-01T02:49Z located at approximately N23E90. This flare is visible in GOES SUVI 131, along with wide field line opening seen in GOES SUVI 171, 195 and 284. Filament ejecta is also visible from this region in association with the flare in GOES SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Updated bulk measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. This measurement focuses on the bright portion of the CME and excludes the faint outer shock feature.
SHOCK measurement focusing on the faint feature surrounding the bulk portion. Measured parameters based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.
PRELIMINARY BULK measurement based on source location and best fit in early frames of SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. This event follows in the path of/overlaps with CME: 2025-12-01T02:48Z. The source is likely related to subsequent eruptive activity from Active Region 14299 following the X1.9-class flare peaking at 2025-12-01T02:49Z, which was associated with CME: 2025-12-01T02:48Z. There is additional brightening/eruptive activity centered near N22E85 as seen in GOES SUVI 131,171,193,284,304 imagery starting around 2025-12-01T03:20Z which may be associated with this event. An opening of field lines is observed over the northeast limb at this time in GOES SUVI 195 and 284 imagery as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This event is visible to the northeast in STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. This CME is not visible in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery in real-time due to an planned extended gap between downlink periods. The source is an eruption from Active Region 14299 (N25E85) starting around 2025-12-01T13:30Z seen in GOES SUVI 131/284/304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery.

cmes.note: Minor, faint CME to the ESE seen in CCOR-1, COR2A, and fully covered by a data gap in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. No clear source was found, but this CME may be related to an eruption from AR 14294 (S15E47) starting around 2025-12-01T14:20Z, as seen in GOES SUVI 304/195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs (GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2). During this analysis SOHO LASCO imagery was not available.

cmes.note: A minor CME to the ESE in GOES CCOR-1, SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2, following in the footsteps of CME: 2025-12-01T15:08Z. The start might be earlier, as it is covered by a data gap in SOHO LASCO. No clear source has been found for this CME on the solar disk, however a possible culprit is Active Region 14294 that has minor activity today.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs (GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2).

cmes.note: Narrow, faint CME first seen to the SSE in GOES CCOR-1 starting at 2025-12-02T05:15Z. This feature is only seen in GOES CCOR-1. The source of this CME is most likely a filament eruption near the SE limb starting as early as 2025-12-01T23:24Z best seen in GOES SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement chosen due to lack of available triangulation.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the SSW in GOES CCOR-1 around 2025-12-02T06:15Z. This narrow CME is only seen in GOES CCOR-1 and SOHO LASCO C3. The source of this CME is likely a small eruption with some associated ejecta near the SW limb in GOES SUVI 284 around S45 starting around 2025-12-02T05:48Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement using a longitude of W90 due to source near the limb and lack of STEREO A COR2 to triangulate the source.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the east in GOES CCOR-1 imagery, and to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 due to flipped imagery following a keyhole maneuver. This event is likely far-sided and therefore not observed in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is a filament eruption visible near the eastern limb in GOES SUVI 304 imagery which begins to lift off around 2025-12-03T01:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the approximate source location. As this event is not observed in STEREO A COR2 imagery, a triangulated measurement was not possible. The measured parameters may vary slightly as a result.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the northeast in STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. This event is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery in real-time due to flipped imagery following a keyhole maneuver. The source is likely related to a dimming region centered near N45E45 first visible around 2025-12-03T05:20Z in GOES SUVI 195 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely a filament eruption starting around 2025-12-03T10:30Z which spans S25W25 to S10W65 seen in GOES SUVI 131/171/195/284/304 and STEREO A EUVI 195/304 imagery. An opening of field lines can be observed over the western limb at this time and post eruptive arcades begin to form around 2025-12-03T14:00Z seen in GOES SUVI 195/304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2, GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. This event is faint and likely a halo as observed by STEREO A, making

cmes.note: A narrower follow-up CME front following 2025-12-03T11:06Z CME and seen to the NW in SOHO LASCO and GOES CCOR-1 and to the north in STEREO A COR2. Its source could be a part of a very long filament eruption stretching from S20W25 to N20W70 and also associated with the 2025-12-03T11:06Z CME. Its front in STEREO A COR2 could be the second northern, faint halo (partial), following the earlier full halo associated with the 2025-12-03T11:06Z CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very approximate analysis based on the fit of a very faint second halo in STEREO A COR2 with the rather messy follow-up to 2025-12-03T11:06Z CME, front seen in SOHO LASCO and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: Narrow faint CME to the E seen in GOES CCOR-1 and (after a data gap) in SOHO LASCO C3. Covered by a daily data gap in STEREO A. The source could be a faint movement of field lines far behind the E limb in GOES SUVI 195 around 2025-12-03T20Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: In the absence of STEREO A imagery and the absence of on-disk source (a faint potential far-sided source has been found) only plane-of-sky analysis is possible.

cmes.note: Faint narrow pointy-nosed CME to the N in SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1. Start is likely earlier. The CME is covered by the daily gap in STEREO A COR2. Its source is possibly an eruption behind the NW limb starting at 2025-12-03T22:30Z and seen as opening/movement of field lines in GOES SUVI 195 and 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: In the absence of STEREO A imagery and the likely far-sided source only plane-of-sky analysis is possible.

cmes.note:
CME: 2025-12-03T23:18Z (C3) SW 
Faint CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 coronagraphs and covered by a daily data gap in STEREO A COR2. Its start is likely much earlier (there is a temporary data gap in SOHO LASCO C2 currently). It source is possibly a minor movement of field lines (and possibly faint post-eruptive arcades) on/behind the SW limb seen in GOES SUVI 195 and 284 after 2025-12-03T19Z.
Screenshot 2025-12-03 at 8.57.37PM.png

cmeAnalyses.note: Because of the absence of STEREO A COR2 imagery for this CME and potential source being behind the limb, only plane-of-sky analysis is possible.

cmes.note: This CME is faintly seen to the W in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1. It is not clearly seen in STEREO A COR2 imagery. There is no clear source for this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky best fit using SWPC_CAT and SOHO imagery. Event is faint, so there may be some uncertainty with speed.

cmes.note: Faint CME observed to the E in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2. The source is an M6.0 class flare from AR 14300 (N10E58) which peaked at 2025-12-04T02:50Z best observed in GOES SUVI 131. Additionally observed as wide field line movement/EUV wave in GOES SUVI 171/195/284, with some dimming around the region in GOES SUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2, finding a good fit with some deflected away from the observed flare source at N10E58.

cmes.note: Faint CME observed to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2, wispy front that becomes more defined further into the coronagraph's field-of-view. The source may be observed as field line movement to the NE in GOES SUVI 284, it is not clear where this traces to on the disk but it may be outflow following the M6.0 from AR 14300 (N10E58), which peaked at 2025-12-04T02:50Z, that is associated with CME 2025-12-04T03:24Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. The CME distorts and expands from early frames in LASCO C2, so only later frames in C3 and COR2A are used when it takes its more final shape.

cmes.note: Bright, wide CME observed to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2. The source is likely slow, wide field line movement beginning around 2025-12-04T04:30Z in GOES SUVI 195/284, with brightening in GOES SUVI 171/195, centered around S21E48.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between SOHO LASCO C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: Faint CME observed to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2. The source is unclear and the best candidate may be a small filament eruption to the NE in GOES SUVI 304 starting around 2025-12-04T07:40Z centered around N30E50, but this is a large deflection to the observed CME, so it is unlikely.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: Narrow, odd shaped, faint event to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. There isn't a clear source for this CME but may be associated with outflow along the western limb or ejecta material from AR 14298 (S16W05).

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on plane-of-sky fit using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

cmes.note: Narrow CME seen only in a few frames to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2 and possibly to the southeast in STEREO A COR2A before a large data gap after 2025-12-04T12:48Z. Likely associated with a narrow eruption from near the central meridian near Active Region 14298 (S16E02) with a minor eruption that deflects sharply to the west.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge, plane of sky measurement using SOHO C2 frames only.
